projects.name: CafKernzaSmallPlotObs
projects.description:
## Long-term trial of the perennial grain crop Kernza (Thinophyrum intermedium) in both the annual, transitional, and fallow agroecological classes of the iPNW focussing on changes in seed yield performance and impact on soil water content

### Rationale
Perennial grains currently occupy a niche market, however, they hold great promise in the way of ecosystem services through the improvement of nitrogen and water use efficiency. This research will be one of the first to conduct a multi-location long-term observational study of the perennial grain crop in the iPNW. The study will determine the feasibility of growing Kernza in all three of the AECs and therefore, results will hold utility for many farmers.

Perennial crops can utilize more of the total precipitation throughout the year compared to annual cropping systems. Perennial grains, such as Kernza, produce a food product like that of annual wheat. In the annual agroecological class, Kernza may be able to reduce erosion and utilize more of the winter and spring precipitation. In the fallow agroecological class, Kernza may serve as a perennial living cover that can reduce wind erosion and serve as a forage crop when rainfall is too low for economically viable grain production.

### Methods
Experimental locations will be established at the Palouse Conservation Field Station, the Washington State Universiy Wilke Farm, and in the Horse Heaven Hills. Each location will be spring seeded with cycle-8 Kernza from The Land Institute and will be in production for at least three years. To disentangle the effect of year and stand age, plots will be set up using a modified-staggered-start design. A similar design has been used successfully for perennial wheat (Triticum aestivum x Thinopyrum intermedium). Each year for three consecutive years two blocks of six total will be seeded. Each block will contain a single strip of Kernza that is split into two treatments. The treatments are designed to alter the amount of inter- and intra-species competition. In the competitive treatment, Kernza is seeded with a nurse crop of spring wheat and then is allowed to grow without any cultivation. The other treatment has no nurse crop and maintains interrow space through cultivation.

A weather station will be deployed at each location to gather basic weather data. Soil moisture content will be measured down to 200 cm using a neutron moisture meter. In the establishment year, stand counts will be taken for the Kernza as well as the spring wheat. Spring wheat yield will be taken along with RGB and Rapideye imaging of the plot to calculate the percentage vegetative area in the fall of both treatments. Each production year each plot will be imaged in the spring and fall to determine the vegetative area. Growing degree days to reach anthesis will be measured along with plant height and lodging once flowering has ceased. Total plot yield along with three 50 cm transects from each plot will be taken to determine yield components. From each transect, the number of reproductive tillers (those containing a spike) will be counted, and five representative spikes will be sub-sampled. The rest of the spikes will be threshed to gain a measure of yield. The five spikes will be used to gather yield components that will consist of fertile tiller number, spike length, spikelets per spike, florets per spikelet, seeds per spike, seed weight, and seed size.

The analysis of a modified staggered start design allows for the simultaneous estimation of the effect of time on stand establishment and subsequent seed crops, but also allows the ability to make contrasts between multiple stand ages within a single location-year environment. This allows an unbiased estimate of changes in seed yield over time as stands age under two contrasting management regimes. Statistically, a linear mixed model is parameterized so that year and time have two separate functionalities. Year is introduced as a qualitative variable and used as a random effect, whereas time is a quantitative variable and is modeled as a fixed effect. In this way, calendar year is meant to account for the random climatic changes being imposed on the crop while time simply models the elapsed period of aging on the crop. The full random effect statement includes year, block, and its interaction with treatment and time. The fixed effects term includes treatment, time, treatment x time, and year x treatment. Notice that treatment interacts with both year and time. This statement will test two hypotheses: (1) is there a linear change in a response variable (e.g. seed yield) over time with respect to the treatment; and (2) is there a random impact of year on a given response variable (e.g. stand establishment) with respect to treatment. As the three experimental locations represent extreme contrasts in precipitation, it is anticipated that three separate models will be required to successfully explain these data.

projects.name: CookSoilHealthBacteriaAndYield
projects.description:
## Purpose

(temporary, copied from email by Tim Paulitz)

"I think the main thing to explore with this paper is to pick out communities that are highly correlated with yield, whether relative yields or actual yields. My guess is both should be highly correlated to each other, if the data is good, but we seemed to be settling on relative yield.  The strength of relative yields is we can bundle across years and remove some of the year to year variation.  That is why I want to explore longer term trends on the East Side, under no till.   But we would still like to look year to year, with individual crops-  maybe these bacteria promote yield of cereals, but not legumes.  It is also evident that there are strong tillage interactions.  In Dan's last analysis, we found that some of these effects were significant in the conventional but not the no-till side.  But I think we are consensing on the idea of using relative yields, based on the averages of the entire farm, not just the samples we took. So we could calculate a average yield for the east side and one for the west side and base all the sites on this."

## Contributors

* Timothy Paulitz, timothy.paulitz@usda.gov
* Daniel Schlatter, daniel.schlatter@usda.gov
* David  Huggins, david.huggins@usda.gov
* Ian Leslie, ian.leslie@usda.gov
* Bryan Carlson, bryan.carlson@usda.gov

projects.name: CookSoilHealthSurvey2017
projects.description:
## Purpose

In 2017 soil cores were taken from the Cook fields to assess soil health. A total of 60 georeferenced points (30 from each field) were selected and nearby soil was sampled at two depth increments (0-10 cm, 10 cm - 20 cm). The samples were analyzed for soil health related attributes including nutrients, PLFAs, and DNA.

## Contributors

* Dave Huggins, david.huggins@usda.gov
* Tim Paulitz, timothy.paulitz@usda.gov
* Ian Leslie, ian.lesie@usda.gov
* Dan Schlatter, daniel.schlatter@usda.gov
* Jeremy Hansen, jeremy.hansen@usda.gov
* Bryan Carlson, bryan.carlson@usda.gov

dataset.name: PLANT_F211575000_USDA-ARS_070621-161719
dataset.description:
Plant Analysis Report from A & L Great Lakes Laboratories. Archived grain samples from harvest years 2017, 2018, and 2019 from CookEast and CookWest were sent out for analysis on 06/15/2021.

Analysis of the grain was primarily to assess total P. These data contribute to constructing a mass-balance analysis of P at the CAF LTAR including P inputs, outputs and change in soil storage. In addition, these data contribute to research efforts of the LTAR network P working group.

Project folder also contains a PDF report of the same results.

dataset.name: Tabulated Data
dataset.description:
From "Nitrate in Tile Drainage of the Semiarid Palouse Basin" by Keller et. al [ https://doi.org/10.2134/jeq2006.0515]: "From 2000–2004 we monitored the discharge of a tile drain (TD) and a nearby profile of soil water for nitrate concentration ([NO3]), electrical conductivity level (EC), and water content to develop a conceptual framework describing soil nitrate occurrence and loss via subsurface pathways."

Dataset is an Excel file with sample locations separated into individual worksheets.

dataset.name: CookSoilHealthPrsPlfa2017
dataset.description:
This dataset contains soil health data for 60 soil cores, at two depth increments (0-10 cm, 10 cm - 20 cm), collected within a catchment areas within Cook East and Cook West. The dataset was created by merging results from various soil health analysis (PRS analysis by Western Ag Innovations, Soil Analysis by Midwest Laboratories, and PLFA analysis by Jeremy Hansen). Columns were renamed from original files to aid in import into ESRI ArcMap. 

This dataset was cleaned by Bryan Carlson from a project-specific dataset created by Ian Leslie (see CE_CWallPRS_SHyieldPFLAE2017_20181030.csv). Many columns were removed to make the dataset applicable for general use.

dataset.name: SampleProcessing_GrainSubSample01
dataset.description:
This dataset contains data entry template (DET) files for tracking sample of canola grain that have been processed for analysis in a third-party lab. This dataset does not contain actual measurements. 

The sample processing documented by this DET is separate from, but related to, the processing recorded in the "Harvest01" (and similar) DETs. 

Each DET file is copied from the "transient" data zone by a Logic App named "SampleProcessing_GrainSubSample01_{YYYY}" where (YYYY} is the four digit year for which the crop was harvested (the harvest year). Any additions found in each of the DET files are incorporated into a "master DET" that is located in the "work" data zone.
dataset.filePathDescriptor: {YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.SS} is the ISO 86001 datetime in UTC format for which the file was copied from the "transient" data zone to its current location. {YYYY} is the four digit year for which the crop was harvested (i.e. harvest year). {INL} are the initials for the individual who has entered the data into the DET. {YYYYMMDD} is the ISO 86001 date for when the DET was copied from the "master" DET and downloaded for editing by the data entry personnel.
methods: File is uploaded to the transient data zone via (this is specific to harvest year 2021): <https://github.com/cafltar/CafLogisticsSampleProcessing_FileTransferScripts/tree/master/GrainSubSample01_2021> then processed by Logic App (specific to harvest year 2021): "SampleProcessing_GrainSubSample01_2021"

dataset.name: AggregatedFilesBoydNorthFlux_v18329
dataset.description: Aggregated values, with quality control flags, of the "Flux" datatable from the eddy covariance flux tower located on the Boyd North field. This dataset is generated from the respective dataset in the "Raw" data zone (raw/CafMeteorologyECTower/BoydNorthFlux_V18329). A single file is generated manually on a nearly daily basis and represents all data, to current date of generation, of the current "crop year" (aka "hydrologic year"); Oct 1 to current.
dataset.filePathDescriptor: {YYYY} is four digit crop year (Oct 1 to Sept. 30), {YYYYMMDD} is four digit year, two digit month, two digit day that the file was generated.

dataset.name: AggregatedFilesBoydSouthFlux_v18329
dataset.description: Aggregated values, with quality control flags, of the "Flux" datatable from the eddy covariance flux tower located on the Boyd South field. This dataset is generated from the respective dataset in the "Raw" data zone (raw/CafMeteorologyECTower/BoydSouthFlux_V18329). A single file is generated manually on a nearly daily basis and represents all data, to current date of generation, of the current "crop year" (aka "hydrologic year"); Oct 1 to current.
dataset.filePathDescriptor: {YYYY} is four digit crop year (Oct 1 to Sept. 30), {YYYYMMDD} is four digit year, two digit month, two digit day that the file was generated.

dataset.name: AggregatedFilesCookEastFlux_v40826
dataset.description: Aggregated values, with quality control flags, of the "Flux" datatable from the eddy covariance flux tower located on the Cook East field. This dataset is generated from the respective dataset in the "Raw" data zone (raw/CafMeteorologyECTower/CookEastFlux_V40826). A single file is generated manually on a nearly daily basis and represents all data, to current date of generation, of the current "crop year" (aka "hydrologic year"); Oct 1 to current.
dataset.filePathDescriptor: {YYYY} is four digit crop year (Oct 1 to Sept. 30), {YYYYMMDD} is four digit year, two digit month, two digit day that the file was generated.

dataset.name: AggregatedFilesCookWestFlux_v40826
dataset.description: Aggregated values, with quality control flags, of the "Flux" datatable from the eddy covariance flux tower located on the Cook West field. This dataset is generated from the respective dataset in the "Raw" data zone (raw/CafMeteorologyECTower/CookWestFlux_V40826). A single file is generated manually on a nearly daily basis and represents all data, to current date of generation, of the current "crop year" (aka "hydrologic year"); Oct 1 to current.
dataset.filePathDescriptor: {YYYY} is four digit crop year (Oct 1 to Sept. 30), {YYYYMMDD} is four digit year, two digit month, two digit day that the file was generated.

dataset.name: SampleProcessing_GrainSubSample01
dataset.description:
This dataset is the "master" data entry templates (DET) for tracking sample of canola grain that have been processed for analysis in a third-party lab. This dataset does not contain actual measurements. 

As a "master" DET, it is the "single source of truth" with the most current information. 

The sample processing documented by this DET is separate from, but related to, the processing recorded in the "Harvest01" (and similar) DETs. 

This dataset is downloaded and renamed to be edited by a data entry personnel. Once edits are complete the edited file is uploaded to the "transient" data zone and incorporated back into this "master" dataset by a Logic App named "SampleProcessing_GrainSubSample01_{YYYY}" where (YYYY} is the four digit year for which the crop was harvested (the harvest year). 

The metadata here largely describe a single file that is updated as new samples are processed. However, the dataset directory also contains an "Archives" folder with previous versions of this file.
dataset.filePathDescriptor: {YYYY} is the four digit year for which the crop was harvested (i.e. harvest year). {INL} are the initials for the individual who has entered the data into the DET. {YYYYMMDD} is the ISO 86001 date for when the DET was copied from the "master" DET and downloaded for editing by the data entry personnel.
methods: Files from the "raw" zone are incorporated into this file via the Azure Function script found here: <https://github.com/cafltar/CafLogisticsSampleProcessing_MergeExcelDetWithMasterDet>

dataset.name: TerrainAtrib10m2_v1
dataset.description:
Data cleaning from legacy project. Notes by Bryan Carlson after talking to David Huggins:

  * Input data has EM38 data for all 369 georeferenced locations on Cook East
  * Spring and Fall data, year 2000
  * 10 m resolution
  * Original (raw?) dataset has values from kinematic survey from 1 m to 30 m, input data for this dataset is just 10 m estimates
  * Geonics EM38 instrument attached to four-wheeler, collecting data as drive around field 
  * Corrected for temperature drifts for differences of temp during day of measurement
  * Units: milli siemons per meter
  * Used vertical dipole (where signal travels, shallow vs deeper; horizontal is not as deep)
dataset.filePathDescriptor: {YYYYMMDD} is date file was generated, where YYYY is four digit year, MM is two digit month, DD is two digit day

dataset.name: RelativeYieldAverage1999_2015_v1
dataset.description: This dataset contains the average relative yield for a given geolocation (ID2) on the Cook East field. Average relative yield was found by taking the yield value at a given point and dividing it by the mean value of the given treatment (usually "strip", but in Field C some treatments were spread across multiple strips) and the given year; then averaging the relative yields for each year of data (from 1999 to 2015).

dataset.name: CookSoilHealthPrsPlfa2017
dataset.description:
This dataset contains soil health data for 60 soil cores, at two depth increments (0-10 cm, 10 cm - 20 cm), collected within a catchment areas within Cook East and Cook West. The dataset was created by merging results from various soil health analysis (PRS analysis by Western Ag Innovations, Soil Analysis by Midwest Laboratories, and PLFA analysis by Jeremy Hansen). Columns were renamed from original files to aid in import into ESRI ArcMap. 

This dataset was cleaned by Bryan Carlson from a project-specific dataset created by Ian Leslie (see CE_CWallPRS_SHyieldPFLAE2017_20181030.csv). Many columns were removed to make the dataset applicable for general use.

dataset.name: ltar_experiments_bndy_a_caf_v2020
dataset.description:
GIS file with polygons of experimental boundaries for CookEast and CookWest. This shapefile was created as part of “LTAR Standard GIS Data Layer v2020”: https://data.nal.usda.gov/dataset/long-term-agroecosystem-research-ltar-network-standard-gis-data-layers-2020-version.

The data contains "legacy" boundaries of the field+strip designation used on CookEast from 1999 to 2015. It also contains the C01 and C02 designation used for CookEast in 2016. And, the CE and CW designations for CookEast and CookWest, respectively.

Data are in WGS84.

Note that field+strip designations are not 1:1 with "TreatmentId" used in other datasets. These are boundary designations, not treatment.
dataset.filePathDescriptor: {YYYYMMDD} = ISO date when file was generated

dataset.name: VolumetricWaterContentFromRevisedBd_P2
dataset.description:
Calculate volumetric water content using legacy gravimetric water content measurements and revised/QC'd/Production-level bulk density values.

The gravimetric data was originally used to calculate volumetric through "representative" bulk density values taken at locations with similar soil types instead of the same location that gravimetric was measured. This effort is to use more representative bulk density data.

See: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhydrol.2011.04.029

Also note that there is a related dataset not current in the data lake that contains modeled values for missing points.

**2021-09-07**: Updated dataset with dates of soil sampling for GWC (sampled used for bulk density was collected at different dates).

dataset.name: AgroecologicalClasses_v1
dataset.description:
Raster map that depicts land-cover classification (urban, rangeland, forest, water, wetlands, barren, wilderness) and agricultural land-use classifications (annual cropping, annual crop fallow transition, grain fallow, irrigated, orchard). Each pixel represents 30 m2. 

Each map represents 1 year and was generated from land-use data defined by the USDA Cropland Data Layer (https://www.nass.usda.gov/Research_and_Science/Cropland/SARS1a.php).
dataset.filePathDescriptor:
{YYYY}/ represents the year the data were generated, where YYYY is a four digit year
{YYYY} represents the year of the USDA Cropland Data Layer used, where YYYY is a four digit year
{YYYYMMDD} represents the date the file was generated, where YYYY is four digit year, MM is two digit month, DD is two digit day

variables.name: Value
variables.description:
Pixel classification, where:

Value		Classification
-----		--------------
1			Urban
3			Rangeland
4			Forest
5			Water
6			Wetlands
7			Barren
9			Wilderness
11			Annual Crop
12			Annual Crop Fallow Transition
13			Grain Fallow
14			Irrigated
15			Orchard

dataset.name: Anthrome_v1
dataset.description:
Raster map that depicts stable (no change in 10 years) and dynamic (at least one change in 10 years) land-cover classification (agriculture, rangeland, forest, water and other, urban) as defined by the higher order Anderson Classification System (see Table 2; https://pubs.usgs.gov/pp/0964/report.pdf). Each pixel represents 30 m2. 

This map was generated from 10 years of land-use data defined by the USDA Cropland Data Layer (https://www.nass.usda.gov/Research_and_Science/Cropland/SARS1a.php).

{YYYYMMDD} represents the date the file was generated, where YYYY is four digit year, MM is two digit month, DD is two digit day

dataset.name: SoilCore1999To2015ShallowDeepMergedByHorizon_v1
dataset.description:
Data from soil cores collected at georeference points located in Cook East. The dataset is an aggregation of values from profile samples (1.5 m depth) subdivided by horizon and values from 30 cm depth soil cores subdivided by 10 cm depth increments. Samples were collected in 1998, 2008, and 2015.

2020-12-21: Data updated. A copy/paste error was identified and fixed that affected bulk density data for ID2=189 for years 1998 and 2008. Also, some values of 0 were identified as null and set to NA; variables for pH and relating to C and N concentration were affected.

dataset.name: CookTerrainAttributes10m2_P3A1_v1
dataset.description: Terrain attributes were generated using SAGA (System for Automated Geoscientific Analysis, http://www.saga-gis.org/). A 10 m2 digital elevation model was created from point data collected in October 2016 (Cook East field) and March 2017 (Cook West field) for input into SAGA. Terrain attribute values were generated for both Cook East and Cook West fields. A spatial layer of the 619 georeference points were overlaid on the terrain attributes and values extracted at each location of the georeferenced points. The output were later cleaned and standardized.
dataset.filePathDescriptor: {YYYYMMDD} is date file was generated, where YYYY is four digit year, MM is two digit month, DD is two digit day

variables.name: ID2
variables.description: Number ID of georeference point

variables.name: FieldName
variables.description: Name of field where georeference point (ID2) resides, either "CookEast" or "CookWest"

variables.name: Latitude
variables.description: Latitude of georeference point; WGS84

variables.name: Longitude
variables.description: Longitude of georeference point; WGS84

variables.name: Elevation
variables.description: Height above sea level

variables.name: AnalyticalHillshade
variables.description: The angle between the surface and the incoming light beams, measured in radians.
methods: Tarini, M. / Cignoni, P. / Montani, C. (2006): Ambient Occlusion and Edge Cueing to Enhance Real Time Molecular Visualization. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, Vol. 12, No. 5, pp. 1237-1244.

variables.name: ConvergenceIndex
variables.description: This module calculates an index of convergence/divergence regarding to overland flow.
methods: Koethe, R. & Lehmeier, F. (1996): SARA - System zur Automatischen Relief-Analyse. User Manual, 2. Edition [Dept. of Geography, University of Goettingen, unpublished]

variables.name: TotalCatchmentArea
variables.description: Catchment area, original, run off area of above-situated grid cells

variables.name: TopographicWetnessIndex
variables.description: Calculation of the slope and specific catchment area based Topographic Wetness Index. It shows water accumulation. This can be useful for soil or flood mapping
methods: Moore, I.D., Grayson, R.B., Ladson, A.R. (1991). Digital terrain modelling: a review of hydrogical, geomorphological, and biological applications. Hydrological Processes, Vol.5, No.1

variables.name: LengthSlopeFactor
variables.description: Length-slope factor accounts for effects of topography on erosion. In the equation, β is slope in degree
methods: Moore, I.D., Grayson, R.B., Ladson, A.R. (1991). Digital terrain modelling: a review of hydrogical, geomorphological, and biological applications. Hydrological Processes, Vol.5, No.1

variables.name: ChannelNetworkBaseLevel
variables.description: Contains  the interpolated channel network base level elevations.

variables.name: ChannelNetworkDistance
variables.description: The altitude above the channel network.

variables.name: ValleyDepth
variables.description: Valley depth is calculated as difference between the elevation and an interpolated ridge level.

variables.name: RelativeSlopePosition
variables.description: Normalized value from 0 (bottom) to 1 (top) for summit positions.
methods: Böhner, Jürgen, and Th Selige. "Spatial prediction of soil attributes using terrain analysis and climate regionalisation." (2006): 13-28.

Moghaddam, D. D., Rahmati, O., Haghizadeh, A., & Kalantari, Z. (2020). A Modeling Comparison of Groundwater Potential Mapping in a Mountain Bedrock Aquifer: QUEST, GARP, and RF Models. Water, 12(3), 679.

variables.name: Slope
variables.description: Measure the rate of changes of elevation in the direction of steepest descent
methods: Zevenbergen, L.W., Thorne, C.R. (1987): Quantitative analysis of land surface topography. Earth Surface Processes and Landforms, 12: 47-56.

variables.name: Aspect
variables.description: The orientation of the line of steepest descent and is usually measured in degrees clockwise from North.
methods: Wilson, J.P. and Gallant, J.C. (2000) Digital Terrain Analysis. In: Wilson, J.P. and Gallant, J.C., Eds., Terrain Analysis: Principles and Applications, John Wiley & Sons, New York, 1-27.

variables.name: TRASP
variables.description: A linear transformation of the circular aspect variable, a continuous variable between 0-1. 0: coolest and wetness orientation; 1: hotter and dryer south-southwesterly slopes.
methods: Roberts, D.W., Cooper, S.V., 1989. Concepts and techniques of vegetation mapping. In: Land Classifications Based on Vegetation: Applications for Resource Management. USDA Forest Service General Technical Report INT-257, Ogden, UT, pp. 90–96.

Huggins, D.R. and Uberuaga, D.P., 2010. Field heterogeneity of soil organic carbon and relationships to soil properties and terrain attributes. Climate friendly farming: Center for Sustaining Agriculture and Natural Resources Research Report 2010–001.

variables.name: ProfileCurvature
variables.description: Measures the rate of change of slope down a flow line and is important for characterizing changes in flow velocity and sediment transport process.
methods: Wilson, J.P., 2018. Environmental Applications of Digital Terrain Modeling. John Wiley & Sons.                                                      Olaya, V. (2006): Basic Land-Surface Parameters. In: Hengl, T., Reuter, H.I. [Eds.]: Geomorphometry: Concepts, Software, Applications. Developments in Soil Science, Elsevier, Vol.33, 141-169.

variables.name: PlanCurvature
variables.description: Measures the rate of change of aspect along a contour line and is important for characterizing the propensity for water to converge or diverge
methods: Wilson, J.P., 2018. Environmental Applications of Digital Terrain Modeling. John Wiley & Sons.                                                      Olaya, V. (2006): Basic Land-Surface Parameters. In: Hengl, T., Reuter, H.I. [Eds.]: Geomorphometry: Concepts, Software, Applications. Developments in Soil Science, Elsevier, Vol.33, 141-169.

variables.name: TangentialCurvature
variables.description: It is the curvature in an inclined plane perpendicular to both the direction of flow and the surface. Provides info for studying convergence and divergence
methods: Wilson, J.P., 2018. Environmental Applications of Digital Terrain Modeling. John Wiley & Sons.                                                      Olaya, V. (2006): Basic Land-Surface Parameters. In: Hengl, T., Reuter, H.I. [Eds.]: Geomorphometry: Concepts, Software, Applications. Developments in Soil Science, Elsevier, Vol.33, 141-169.
